answers: seals [or cylinder seals; or roller stamps]
parts: Identify this UNESCO World Heritage Site whose highest central block contains a mudbrick Great Bath.
The robed male soapstone sculpture from Mohenjo-daro is one of the few works of art recovered from the long-lived civilization named for this South Asian river's valley.
The best evidence of the Indus Civilization's writing system comes from the thousands of these items, many of which have an animal on them. "Cylinder" examples are found throughout Mesopotamia.

answers: Symphony of Sorrowful Songs [accept but do not otherwise reveal Henryk Górecki’s Symphony No. 3; or Górecki’s Third Symphony]
minimalism [or minimal music; accept holy minimalism]
parts: Name this 1976 symphony for soprano and orchestra by a Polish School composer. Each of its movements is based on a different text about Mary, the second of which was found on the wall of a Gestapo jail cell.
Henryk Górecki’s (“goo-RET-skee’s”) Symphony of Sorrowful Songs was given this number. Beethoven’s symphony of this number is nicknamed “Eroica.”
The Symphony of Sorrowful Songs exemplifies a type of this compositional style often called “holy” or “sacred.” Process music and phase music are considered subtypes of this musical style.

answers: pirates [accept A General History of the Robberies and Murders of the most notorious Pyrates; prompt on sailors or criminals]
junks [or junco; or jonk; or jong; accept Southern junks]
parts: Name this profession practiced by people such as Mary Read and Anne Bonny. Members of this profession supposedly founded the colony of Libertalia in Madagascar.

One pirate profiled in Johnson's book is this Englishman, born Edward Teach, who captained the Queen Anne’s Revenge and blockaded what is now Charleston. His nickname derives from his prominent facial hair.
Female Chinese pirate Ching Shih once commanded over a thousand of these Chinese sailing vessels. Their square sails often had bamboo battens.

answers: statistical mechanics [or stat mech; accept statistical physics]
ergodic hypothesis [accept word forms such as ergodicity]
second law of thermodynamics [prompt on second law]
parts: Give this subfield of physics that uses probability distributions to analyze the behavior of microscopic systems. It was principally developed for use in thermodynamics.
Statistical mechanics often relies on this assumption that over a lengthy period of time, each accessible microstate of the system has an equal probability of being accessed.
Statistical mechanics can be used to explain this statement regarding systems tending to trend towards configurations with larger entropies.
Name this Nigerian poet whose Path of Thunder includes “Elegy for Alto.” The anthology Don’t Let Him Die commemorates his passing in wartime Biafra.
“Elegy for Alto” was written for performance with this kind of instrument. Traditions surrounding hourglass-shaped “talking” examples of these instruments constitute a West African oral literature.
Okigbo likely inspired the character Okeoma, who stops writing poetry to fight in the Biafran War in Half of a Yellow Sun. That novel is by this author of Americanah.

answers: cities [or towns; prompt on city walls]
parts: Identify these entities. Tyche and other goddesses sacred to these entities were often depicted wearing "mural crowns."
Tyche was also often pictured holding one of these objects, another of which Zeus accidentally broke off the goat Amaltheia.
In some accounts, Tyche is grouped with the three thousand nymphs sired by this Titan, the husband of Tethys.

answers: Fanny Burney [or Frances Burney; or Madame d'Arblay]
parts: This man described the removal of a bladder stone in one entry of his six-volume diary produced during the reign of Charles II that is invaluable to historians.
An 1812 letter by this author describes getting a mastectomy without anesthetics. The Reverend Arthur Villars eventually agrees to let his guardian marry Lord Orville in this author's novel Evelina.
Daniel Defoe presented a horrifying parade of women who died in childbirth in a section from his “journal”describing a year of one of these events in London in 1665.

answers: leisure [accept Theory of the Leisure Class]
meritocracy [or word forms; accept Meritocracy Trap]
longitudinal study [or longitudinal survey; or panel study; or cohort study]
parts: Identify this word which names a class of people in the title of a Thorstein Veblen book.

Daniel Markovits has argued that a “trap” of this system has caused the wealthy to work more. A 1958 Michael Dunlop Young essay popularized this word for a system that supposedly rewards those who work the hardest.

The UK’s General Household Survey, one of these types of studies, examined leisure time. 268 Harvard graduates were tracked for 75 years in another of these studies that repeatedly measure the same variables on the same subjects.

answers: Kenya [or Republic of Kenya] (The mountain is Mount Kenya.)
tea [accept black tea or green tea]
parts: Identify this country whose National Land Commission recently changed lease terms in an attempt to reclaim more white-owned land. This country is home to Africa’s second-tallest mountain.
Kenya’s White Highlands are well suited for growing the leaves used to make this beverage, which the British also introduced into Assam from China.
Kenya’s tea regions have the largest population of members of this religion in Africa. Six people were killed in a shooting in a temple for this religious faith in Oak Creek, Wisconsin, in 2012.

answers: abstracts [accept précis; accept more specific types of abstracts like structured abstracts; prompt on synopsis or summary or thesis; do not accept or prompt on “introductions”]
Marie Curie [or Marie Salomea Skłodowska Curie]
having a Wikipedia article [accept equivalents like being on Wikipedia]
parts: A 2013 study by Glynn et al. found that these parts of scientific papers were rated more favorably when male authors wrote about male-typed topics. Nature’s public website only includes this portion of articles when the articles are not open access.

This Polish-French discoverer of radium is the most prominent exception to the trend of women being overshadowed by their male partners, as she is better known than her Nobel Laureate husband and son-in-law.

It took winning the 2018 Nobel Prize in Physics for Donna Strickland to earn this distinction, which she was previously denied despite co-laureate Gérard Mourou receiving it in 2005. The “Women in Red” project aims to increase the number of women with this distinction.

answers: Walden; or, Life in the Woods [accept The Senses of Walden]
parts: Name this American philosopher whose idea of the "Over-Soul" likely borrows from Eastern religions. In another essay, he advocated the viewpoint of a "transparent eye-ball."
Cavell's other work on transcendentalism includes an account of The Senses of this semi-philosophical book, written by Henry David Thoreau near a namesake pond.
Arthur Versluis posits that this "Buddha of the North" was another major influence on transcendentalist thought. This Scandinavian mystic recorded his visions in Heaven and Hell.
Name this form of mob violence. Women would sometimes throw pillows out their windows in preparation for this process.
17 Wobblies were tarred and feathered in Tulsa in 1917. Four years later, this Tulsa neighborhood, nicknamed “Black Wall Street,” was destroyed in a race massacre.
Several Americans of this ethnicity were tarred and feathered during World War I. Also during the war, sauerkraut was renamed "liberty cabbage" due to prejudice against members of this ethnic group.

answers: American expressionism [accept word forms such as expressionists]
parts: Name this movement represented by Elmer Rice's The Adding Machine and Sophie Treadwell's Machinal. Despite the author's protests, The Hairy Ape and The Emperor Jones are considered part of this largely European art movement.
The late career of this author of The Emperor Jones includes the more realistic Long Day's Journey into Night.
O'Neill had actors in this trilogy employ mask-like facial expressions in a move away from his expressionistic use of masks. This cycle adapts the Oresteia of Aeschylus.

answers: Ruhollah Khomeini [or Ayatollah Khomeini; do not accept or prompt on “Khamenei” or “Ali Khamenei”]
parts: Name this man who was assassinated in 661 CE in Kufa by Kharijites, a sect that repudiated him after he agreed to arbitration. This man is buried at his shrine in Najaf.
During a 14-year exile in Najaf, this modern Shia cleric developed the “guardianship of the jurist” doctrine, arguing a religious scholar should be a nation's supreme leader.
Khomeini ultimately implemented the “guardianship of the jurist” doctrine in this country’s theocratic constitution following its overthrow of the Shah during the Islamic Revolution.

answers: cell culturing [or word forms such as cell culture]
hemolysis [or word forms such as hemolytic; accept descriptive answers indicating that they break down red blood cells]
parts: Name this process of growing cells in controlled conditions.

Cells are often maintained in a phosphate-buffer form of this solution due to its isotonicity and lack of toxicity towards cells. In hospitals, this substance is used in IV bags to maintain hydration.

Cells may be cultured on BAPs to detect if they exhibit this behavior. If they display the alpha form, the agar becomes dark green, its beta form results in a yellow background, and if it does not display it at all it is said to be gamma.

answers: barbed wire [or razor wire; prompt on wire]
Portugal [or Portuguese Republic; or República Portuguesa; or Kingdom of Portugal]
Battle of Amiens [or Third Battle of Picardy]
parts: Identify this technology originally developed for fences in the American West.

The first use of barbed wire in combat may have been at the 1895 Battle of Magul, where colonial troops from this country withstood an attack from Maguiguana. This country established a “factory” at Malacca in 1511 and developed the caravel.
The deployment of over 500 tanks at this World War I battle, the first in the Hundred Days Offensive, helped break the war’s stalemate.

answers: red balloons [or toy balloon; or party balloon; or helium balloon; do not accept or prompt on "hot air balloons"]
parts: Name the heart-shaped object held by a girl in that Banksy painting. A boy is followed around by a red one of these objects in a 1956 short film from France.

Mr. DOB, a character that appears in many works by an artist from this country, was made into a Thanksgiving Day Parade balloon. That artist from this country, Takashi Murakami, employs the superflat style.
This artist used a special mixture of air and helium to fill balloons for his Silver Clouds. A late self-portrait depicts this artist wearing a "Fright Wig."
Name this surprisingly singly-eponymous model of intermolecular interactions whose repulsive term was chosen to be the square root of its attractive term.

This scientist showed that nonpolar molecules experienced forces that scale with distance to the negative sixth as part of his namesake dispersion force, which is considered part of the van der Waals force.

London derived dispersion forces with the multipole expansion, whose second term describes these systems. The classical explanation of dispersion relies on the formation of "instantaneous" examples of these systems.

answers: Caravaggio [accept Michelangelo Merisi, Michele Angelo Merigi, or Amerigi]
Goliath's Head [or testa di Golia; prompt on Goliath by asking "which body part?"; prompt on head by asking "whose head?"]
parts: Name this gorgon whose decapitated snake-covered head was painted onto a shield by a Baroque artist.
This Baroque artist used his own likeness in that painting of Medusa. Judith stands at arm's length as she cuts off Holofernes head in another work by this male painter.

Caravaggio later used his own likeness to depict this specific object. This specific object is held aloft in that painting gifted to Scipione Borghese, possibly in exchange for being pardoned for murder.
Seeking retribution for his wife Elka’s infidelity, the title baker urinates into his town’s bread in this Nobel Laureate’s story “Gimpel the Fool.”

“Gimpel the Fool” draws on the folklore of this religion. This religion also was practiced by the author of the story “Cinnamon Shops,” Bruno Schulz, who was shot dead by a Gestapo officer while carrying a loaf of bread.

A group of pretzel-makers working in a cramped cellar idolize the young seamstress Tanya, but come to revile her after she is wooed by a womanizing soldier, in this author’s social realist story “Twenty-Six Men and a Girl.”

answers: cake walks [accept prize walks; or chalk-line walks or walk-arounds]
parts: Name this “Two Step” piece that Marvin Hamlisch used as theme music for The Sting.
“The Entertainer” is in this genre pioneered by James Scott and Scott Joplin. The latter also wrote pieces in this genre called “Gladiolus” and “Maple Leaf.”
Ragtime was influenced by music for this earlier “plantation dance,” which was later named for the food given to the winning couple at a competition during Philadelphia’s Centennial Exposition.
